bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 165, Number 60 (Monday, April 8, 2019)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. BURCHETT:H.R. 2127.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article IV,Section 3, Clause 2. The Congress shall have Power todispose of and make all needful Rules and Regulationsrespecting the Territory or other Property belonging to theUnited States; and nothing in this Constitution shall be soconstrued as to Prejudice any Claims of the United States, orof any particular State.[Page H3129]

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

summary.text:
No Taxpayer-Funded Art in Embassies Act

This bill prohibits the purchase, installation, insurance, or transport of art for display in a U.S. embassy or consulate.

bill.title: No Taxpayer-Funded Art in Embassies Act

item.title: No Taxpayer-Funded Art in Embassies Act
To prohibit the use of United States Government funds for art in United States embassies and consulates, and for other purposes.
No Taxpayer-Funded Art in Embassies Act

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
